name: Climbing in the Tetons

image_matrix.caption: I went on a 10 day climbing excursion in the Grand Tetons in 1987, guided by the Exum Mountain Guides. We climbed the Grand Teton (13,770 feet), Middle Teton (12,805 feet), and Mount Moran (12,605 feet). It turned out that this proved good preparation for my guided climbs in the Andes with the American Alpine Institute in 1989-1991. Google Earth image.
A sundown scene looking west. Courtesy of Go GrandTetons.
A view of the South, Middle, and Grand Tetons.
On the top of the Grand with two members of the climbing team. Preparation and the climb lasted four days.
A look over at Middle Teton as sunrise casts a golden glow.
On the top of Middle Teton with the Grand behind. This was a two day climb.
Mt. Moran. The vertical Black Dike, as it's known, is a basalt intrusion. Courtesy of FLICKR.
Another view of Mt. Moran. Our route was to the left of the Black Dike.
On the top of Moran. Our guide is on the right. This was a climb of three days.

shortname: The Expedition to Ecuador in January, 1989.
name: The Expedition to Ecuador in January, 1989.

ikarus_data.name: The Expedition to Ecuador in January, 1989.
ikarus_data.shortname: The Expedition to Ecuador in January, 1989.

image_matrix.caption: Earth image of the terrain west of Quito.
A view from 30,000 feet at the main Ecuador peaks. Loren McIntyre.
A jet landing at the old Mariscal Sucre passes right above a residential neighborhood. The guy is using a flame torch to burn weeds, although he seems to be firing at the jet! Courtesy of Wiki.

Blasco Vela marched through Quito on his way north to link with Captain Belalcázar for reinforcements. He passed through Pasto, Colombia seen here. In 1982, the author and his wife traveled to this city to adopt their second daughter. Courtesy of JORGELRM.
Gonzalo Pizarro chose the place of battle on a small plain called IÃ±aquito, here depicted. Artist: I Riquelme.

Edward Whymper climbed many of the peaks in Ecuador and documented his travels in, <u>Travels Amongst the Great Andes of the Equator</u>, written in 1880. We followed his climbing routes on all the peaks we attempted. Painting by Lance Calkin.

Iñaquito is one of 55 parishes in the canton of Quito located towards the north of the city and near the old Mariscal Sucre. Our hotel was located here. There is a large concentration of malls in the area and the population is exceedingly wealthy relative to the rest of Quito. This is also home to a large international community, primarily Americans. Various mission agencies have their Ecuador headquarters here. Courtesy of GOQUITO.

The Ciudad Mitad del Mundo (Middle of the World City) is a tract of land owned by the prefecture of the province of Pichincha, Ecuador. It is located 16 miles north of the center of Quito. The grounds contain the Monument to the Equator, which highlights the exact location of the Equator from which the country takes its name; they also contain the Ethnographic Museum Middle of the Earth, a museum about the indigenous people ethnography of Ecuador. The 98 ft monument was constructed between 1979 and 1982 by Pichincha's Province Council to replace an older, smaller monument built by the Government of Ecuador in 1936. It is made of iron and concrete and covered with cut and polished andesite stone. The monument was built to commemorate the first Geodesic Mission of the French Academy of Sciences. It conducted experiments to test the flattening at the poles of the characteristic shape of the Earth, by comparing the distance between a degree meridian in the equatorial zone to another level measured in Sweden. The older monument was moved 4.3 miles to the town of CalaCali. Courtesy of Yee Wang.

The Otavalo market. Otavalo, capital of Otavalo canton, has a population largely made up of the Otavalo indigenous group. It has 39,354 inhabitants and sits at an elevation of 8,307 feet. It is surrounded by the peaks of Imbabura (15,190 feet), Cotacachi (16,388 ft)), and Mojanda (12,300 feet) volcanoes. The indigenous Otavalo people are famous for weaving textiles, usually made of wool, such as handmade blankets, tablecloths, and much more. Our climbing team visited on Saturday, the famous market day. Courtesy of GRAYLINE.

After spending the morning at the Otavalo market, we hiked through the hills of the town, crossed through fields and eucalyptus groves, and came to Lago San Pedro and had lunch at the restaurant of the Lago Pedro Hotel. Courtesy of INTHEKNOW.

The day after visiting Otavalo, we made our way to the Panecillo. El Panecillo (from Spanish panecillo small piece of bread) is a 650 foot high hill of volcanic-origin located between southern and central Quito. Its peak is at an elevation of 9,895 feet above sea level. The original name used by the aboriginal inhabitants of Quito was Yavirac. There was a temple on top of Yavirac where the Indians worshiped the sun until it was destroyed by the conquistadors. In 1976, the Spanish artist Agustín de la Herrán Matorras was commissioned to build a 150 foot tall stone monument of a Madonna on the top of Panecillo. Called \"Virgin of Panecillo\", it is made of seven thousand pieces of aluminum. The Virgin stands on top of a globe and is stepping on a snake, which is classic Madonna iconography. Less traditional are the wings. Locals claim that she is the only one in the world with wings like an angel. Courtesy of GOQUITO.
The Panecillo in the early evening with Antisana in the distance. Courtesy of NOTIMUNDO.
The Virgin on the top of the Panecillo. Courtesy of VISTA HERMOSA.
The Panecillo with Antisana to the east. Courtesy of ROUGHGUIDES.

The Church and Convent of St. Francis is a 16th-century Roman Catholic complex in Quito, Ecuador and fronts onto its namesake Plaza de San Francisco. The imposing edifice has the distinction of being the largest architectural ensemble among the historical structures of colonial Latin America and for this reason is sometimes known as \"El Escorial of the New World\". The style evolved over almost 143 years of construction (1537-1680) through earthquakes and changes in architectural styles. The Church houses the city's beloved Virgin of Quito (1734). Courtesy of GOECUADOR.

Santo Domingo Church borders the southern edge of Quito Old Town and stands over Santo Domingo Plaza. The church represents fascinating periods in Quitoâs religious history, as it was constructed by Dominicans and modified by Italian priests. The churchâs stately tower features Baroque architectural styling and a city clock. This colonial era Church is well known for its awe-inspiring collection of art, located in the Lady of the Rosary chapel and the church museum. There are magnificent works by noteworthy QuiteÃ±o artists, including carvings, reliefs, and stunning frescos. Also on display is the famous sculpture of the Virgin del Rosario (Our Lady of the Rosary) and fine examples of artworks from the Quito School of Art. Courtesy of VISTA HERMOSA.
La Ronda is a popular attraction in Old Quito, famous for its many shops and cafes, all with a Bohemian edge to them. Courtesy of GOECUADOR.
An 1805 map of the Inca town of Quito. Artist: Juan Pio Montufar.
Another painting of Quito, this from the mid-18th century. Artist: Miguel de Santiago
Another painting of Quito, this one dated 1850. Artist: Rafael Salas.
My new little friend in Quito (1989).
A view of Quito on the road to Lloa. Courtesy of Ricardo Magron.

Pichincha is an active volcano outside Quito, Ecuador. This Edward Whymper woodcut of 1892 shows three of Whymper's guides near the summit. Whymper was a famous naturalist, climber, and artist who climbed extensively in the Alps and the Andes. In 1880, he was the first climber to ascend a high altitude peak, in this case Chimborazo (20,400'). His signature appears in the lower left corner. See the delightful accounts of his climbs and travels in Travels Amongst the Great Andes of the Equator. R. Villarreal Collection.
The village of Lloa on the lower southern slopes of Pichincha. Courtesy of DREAMSTIME.
An Earth image of the area where we started our hike.
This is the Pichincha Refugio at 15,000 feet. We did not visit this place as our guide chose to bypass it to the east on the way to the summit. Courtesy of Frosia Kitova.
The CULCITIUM is a genus of flowering plants that includes 59 described species. Whymper mentions them on the slopes of Pichincha and we saw one near the summit. Courtesy of Rare flowers.
The Guagua summit marker at 15,728 feet. Notice how close to the volcano's crater it is. Courtesy of Quito climbs.
The summit of Guagua Pichincha, 15,728 feet. Courtesy of A. Enriquez.
Pichincha volcano summit (15,700', 4790 m).
This photo captures the 1999 eruption of Pichincha Volcano. I stood on the summit 12 years before this! Courtesy of Wikipedia.
The town of Cayambe, home to 40,000 citizens. Courtesy of youtube.
Whymper's drawing of a lower camp on the slopes of Cayambe.
A view of Cayambe from a point west from the peak. Courtesy of wiki.
Cayambe peak amongst the clouds. Courtesy of Loren McIntyre.
A cock fighting arena in Cayambe. Whymper tells of the mayor managing a cock fighting competition when he visited the town. Courtesy of COCKFIGHTING.

This is the Ruales Oleas Berge Refugio on Cayambe. It accommodates 32 people, has two kitchens, two fireplaces, two living rooms, running water, and toilets. When we got here the guides determined that recent avalanches had covered the lower reaches of the Whymper route, making it too dangerous for us to attempt it. We stayed the night and next day left for Cotopaxi. Courtesy of Riofrio Arias.

El Cayambe (18,996', 5790 m) sits northeast of Quito. Its distinction is that the equator lies right on its southern slopes. We got this close to the peak before the guides determined that the entire lower portion of the Whymper route had been obliterated by avalanches. We pushed on to Cotopaxi.
Upon our departure from El Cayambe, I found another little friend, this one walking her dog.
Original 1892 Whymper woodcut of a puma approaching Whymper's tent on El Cayambe at 14,462' (4408 m). R. Villarreal Collection.
On the descent of El Cayambe, one of the pack animals slipped and fell over a precipice into the void below. Original 1892 Edward Whymper woodcut. R. Villarreal Collection.
The town of Machach to the west of Cotopaxii. Whymper and the Carrels stayed here before tackling Cotopaxi. So did we. Courtesy of ECTravel.
A Google image of the important geographical places mentioned in the text.
The Tambopaxi Lodge where we stayed the night before proceeding on to Cotopaxi (background.) Courtesy of sabana exp.
Cotopaxi from the Rosario Farm. Artist: Edward Whymper.
This is today' Rosario Farm property. It was purchased by the government in 2001 and they converted it into a talapia breeding farm. Courtesy of AQUASOL.
A view east to Cotopaxi. Courtesy of Wiki.
Another view of the mountain. Courtesy of Jorge Anhalzer.
Cotopaxi Park entrance station. Courtesy of Bakhmotov.
Inside the Jose Rivas Refugio. Courtesy of ECTRAVEL.
An aerial view of the Cotopaxi crater. Courtesy of Loren McIntyre.
Another crater view. Courtesy of Loren McIntyre.
Yet another crater view. Courtesy of Loren McIntyre.
Whymper and one of the Carrels peer into the mouth of the crater. Artist: Edward Whymper.

Whymper's drawing of the crater's inside. From A to B was measured by a rope line. C was the lowest point on the rim, while D and E were the highest. Z represents the mouth of the lava pipe at the bottom of the crater.
Base Camp on Cotopaxi -- the Jose Rivas hut at 15,500' (4720 m).
Cotopaxi (19,347', 5897 m).
Another view of the Cotopaxi summit, this one higher on the route.
Whymper wood engraving dated 1892 of the Cotopaxi summit crater. R. Villarreal Collection.
On the return from the fog choked Cotopaxi summit, the mists lift to reveal the rich Ecuadorian countryside.
More stunning views from the flanks of Cotopaxi.
And more.
The city of Ambato, northeast from Chimborazo and northwest from Baños. Courtesy of Andre Hubner.
The eruption of Tungurahua in 1995, as seen from Ambato. Courtesy of ECUATRAVEL.
The main plaza of Baños de Santa Agua. R. Villarreal Collection.

Catholic believers say that the Virgin Mary appeared near a waterfall near the town in the early 20th century. To honor this, a sculpture of the Virgin, called Virgen de Agua Santa, was placed in the city's cathedral. Courtesy of Chaz Thompson.
We stayed at the Hotel Sangay. R. Villarreal Collection.
Cuy, or guinea pigs, are cute! Courtesy of cuynation
Ecuadorians consume 65 million cuy each year! Courtesy of 25dollartravel.
We visited a nearby market and the bread woman was fast asleep! R. Villarreal Collection.
Tungurahua from Baños. Courtesy of Torres Costales.
The town of Baños, with Tungurahua in the distance. Courtesy of viajandox.
Another view of Tungurahua. Courtesy of volcandiscovery.
Another view of Baños. Courtesy of Wiki.
Some of the 60 waterfalls in and around the city. Courtesy of mill 1.
More waterfalls! Courtesy of budget your trip.
A section of the valley walls surrounding Banos, a small town near Tungurahua peak. It resembles Yosemite Valley, with numerous waterfalls that cascade into the valley below.
On the way from Banos to the Tungurahua staging area to rent our pack animals.
This is the Park office where we paid for the arrieros and horses to carry our equipment to the Refugio. R. Villarreal Collection.

This is the route above the Refugio to the summit. Winds came up during the night before our summit attempt and I accompanied our guide at 2 a.m. as he wanted to climb above to see if we could still continue. The winds were too fierce and he had to cancel our attempt on the summit. Courtesy of ivaga tours.
Pack horse for lugging our gear to a refugio on the slopes of Tungurahua volcano (16,475', 5022 m); next day it was too windy to climb.
The Tungurahua hut at 13,000' (4000 m). The wind was blasting the next morning so viciously that we cancelled an attempt on the summit.
This same Tungurahua erupting in April, 2011; the beautiful town of Banos is off to the left.
Another picture of the eruption.

Spanish allies, the ruthless Ca&ntildeari warriors, slaughter Inca Quitan troops at the R&iacuteo Ambato on the Spanish march to Quito in June, 1535. Courtesy of Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.
We're on the way to the Carrel hut on Chimborazo (in the distance). Photo taken from Guarandas.
An Earth view of the landscape around Chimborazo.
An Earth image looking east at the valley between Carihuairazo and Chimborazo.
Looking north at the flanks of Carihuairazo. Chimborazo is behind the photographer. Courtesy of jraudiovideo.
Chimborazo to the east from the streets of Guaranda. Courtesy of PINTEREST.
Another image of Chimborazo from Guaranda. Courtesy of Torres Costales.
\"The early explorers of Chimborazo, Humboldt and Bonpland.\" Artist: Freidrich Georg Weitsch.
\"Chimborazo, the Heart of the Andes.\" Artist: Frederic Edwin Church.
The Tambo of Totorillas. Courtesy of Alberto Bombardelli.
The Arenal, with Chimborazo to the east. Courtesy of Viajando.
Chimborazo Park Entrance Station. Courtesy of ChimboParque.
Earth image of the Park Entrance Station.

1899 original halftone print of Chimborazo by The Werner Company. This image is from Guarandas, very near the spot where I took the picture in the previous image. In both, the Whymper route to the summit is out of sight, over the ridge on the left skyline. R. Villarreal Collection.
This wood-engraving hunting scene most likely was carried out in the area of the previous picture of Chimborazo, near Guarandas. It's another Whymper work dated 1885. R. Villarreal Collection.
The Louis Carrel hut on Chimborazo, at 15,912' (4850 m). Carrel was one of Whymper's climbing guides in Ecuador.
A look down to the Carrel hut on the way up to the Base Camp location of the Whymper hut.
The Whymper hut at 16,404' (5000 m). R. Villarreal Collection.
Close up views of the red cliffs and the Whymper Glacier. Courtesy of Loren McIntyre.

An aerial approaching Chimborazo from the north side, looking south. Whymper climbed El Arenal (the plain of ashes and cinders) under the clouds to the right, and up to the base of the red cliffs. He then crossed to the left to the bottom of the smooth glacier leading to the summit and climbed directly up it to the top. This is known as the \"Whymper Route\" and is the route we followed. Courtesy of Loren McIntyre.

A view of Chimborazo from the Whymper hut. The route follows the ridge to the right. Once above the rock and ice outcropping in the center of the picture, the route traverses to the left skyline and follows the glacier to the summit.
An Earth view of the Carrel and Whymper Refugios on the western slopes.
Frank has found a space for the night in the Whymper hut! R. Villarreal Collection.
Cotopaxi and Antisana from high on Chimborazo. Courtesy of Destination Latine.

This is a picture of the western slopes with the upper part of the western ridge to the right. This was taken from the Whymper Refugio with a Zoom lens. At the top of the ridge, there is a shelf, here seen as the dark rock ledge that stretches from the top of the ridge to the Whymper Glacier to the left. The ledge was some five feet in width, so it was ideal to walk upon it to the Glacier, where we attached our crampons for the climb upwards. Courtesy of SummitPost.
Julie leads the second team to the summit. R. Villarreal Collection.
This is the eastern side of Chimborazo, a more pleasing view, to me, than any other side. Courtesy of Loren McIntyre.
On the top; I'm on the left with our Ecuadorian guide, Rodrigo.
Original 1892 Edward Whymper woodcut as he and his guides try to erect their tent low on the slopes of Chimborazo. R. Villarreal Collection.
Another Whymper engraving showing climbers, at 17,450' (5319 m), above the site of today's Whymper hut as they work their way across the ridge outside camp. R. Villarreal Collection.
Whymper's engraving of the scene higher on the route, at 18,500' (5640 m). R. Villarreal Collection.
Whymper engraving of the route as they close on the summit. R. Villarreal Collection.
Whymper and the Carrels ascended the eastern summit of Chimborazo (20,581 feet) on January 4 of 1880. R. Villarreal Collection.

Louis Carrel contracted frostbite on the climb. A litter was rigged up and he was carried to the nearby town of Ambato for medical treatment Another 1892 woodcut by Edward Whymper. R. Villarreal Collection.
An Earth view of the northwest ridge of Chimborazo, the route to the summit of Whymper's second ascent of the peak.
Whymper's engraving of the eruption of Cotopaxi during his second ascent of Chimborazo.
Whymper and the Carrels ascended Chimborazo for the second time on July 3 of 1880. Edward Whymper engraving. R. Villarreal Collection.

shortname: The Expedition to Bolivia in June, 1990, preceded by a visit to Machu Picchu.
name: The Expedition to Bolivia in June, 1990, preceded by a visit to Machu Picchu.

ikarus_data.name: The Expedition to Bolivia in June, 1990, preceded by a visit to Machu Picchu.
ikarus_data.shortname: The Expedition to Bolivia in June, 1990, preceded by a visit to Machu Picchu.

image_matrix.caption: Governor Pizarro founded the City of Kings on January 18 of 1535, the capital city in the new land of Peru. The name bestowed upon it Pizarro chose in recognition that this day celebrated the feast day of the Epiphany, the day when the three kings visited the Christ child in his manger. Within a few years the name of Lima took its place. Artist unknown.
An engraving of Lima city. Artist: Poma de Ayala.
1846 painting of Lima Cathedral. Artist: unknown.
The Marquess Pizarro hears rumors of his assassination but does not believe them. Artist: Lima de Freitas.
On Sunday, 26 June of 1541, the followers of Almagro the Lad charge through the Lima streets on their way to kill the Marquess. Artist: Edward Bawden.
The men of Chile exact their vengeance upon Francisco Pizarro at his home. Artist: Unknown.
The tomb of Francisco Pizarro in a side chapel of the Lima Cathedral. Courtesy of GOPERU.
Quizo and his warriors attack Francisco Pizarro and his men in the new city of Lima. Courtesy of LISTVERSE.
Quizo camped out on the hill of San Cristobal to avoid the maneuverability of the Spanish horses. Courtesy of Valladares.
General Quizo is cornered by the Spanish and executed. Courtesy of Wiki.

Cuzco, Peru. The Plaza de Armas is at the center in the photo. The present day buildings around the square have the old Inca structures for their foundations. The Almagro Expedition departed the city for Chile on July 3, 1535.
Map of Cusco by E. George Squier. R. Villarreal Collection.
A view of Cusco below from Fortress Sacsayhuaman above. Courtesy of PERUSUMMIT.
The Plaza de Armas with the statue of Inca Pachacuti in the forefront and the Iglesia de CompanÃ­a de JesÃºs behind. Courtesy of PERUTRAVEL.
The distinctive street of Hatun Rumiyoc. Courtesy of GOPERU.

Room at the Hotel Loreto where we stayed when we adopted our daughter in 1978. It occupies part of the structure known as the House of the Virgins of the Sun and was built during the reign of Inca Pachacuti (1438-1471). The walls are made of square stones of polished grey granite.
Another room interior at the Hotel Loreto.
1888 wood engraving of a Cuzco street scene. Publisher: Harper & Brothers. R. Villarreal Collection.
A modern street scene today, this the alley of Hatun Rumiyoq. Courtesy Odyssei.
The city of Cuzco. Original 1875 Engraving by Edouard Riou. Scribner, Armstrong, Co. Publisher. R. Villarreal Collection.
Cuzco street scene in 1978. Some of these buildings pre-date the Conquest and are the original Inca structures. R. Villarreal Collection.
Street scene in Cuzco from a hotel balcony in 1989. These buildings haven't changed since the Conquest. R. Villarreal Collection.

Antique print, titled âA Birdâs Eye View of Cusco, a City in Peru and the Principal City of the Region and Province of the Same Name.â This engraving originates from Sebastian Munsterâs âCosmographia, Beschreibung aller Lenderâ. It is from the 1592 German edition, published in Basel by Henrichum Petri. Munster, a German cartographer, cosmographer, and Christian scholar is best known for âCosmographiaâ, the earliest German description of the world, in six parts. R. Villarreal Collection.
Inca Temple of the Sun in Cuzco. 1994. The Temple was used by the Incas at the time of, and before, the Conquest. R. Villarreal Collection.
Rustic street scene in Cuzco in 2000. R. Villarreal Collection.

Cusco, Peru. From: 'De Nieuwe en Onbekende Weereld: of beschryving van America en 't Zuid-Land.', by Arnoldus Montanus, published in Amsterdam by Jacob van Meurs in 1671. (The New and Unknown World: or Description of America and the Southland, Containing the Origin of the Americans and South-landers, remarkable voyages thither, Quality of the Shores, Islands, Cities, Fortresses, Towns, Temples, Mountains, Sources, Rivers, Houses, the nature of Beasts, Trees, Plants and foreign Crops, Religion and Manners, Miraculous Occurrences, Old and New Wars: Adorned with Illustrations drawn from the life in America, and described by Arnoldus Montanus). The book was translated and published in England by the editor and map publisher John Ogilby under the title, America, Being an Accurate Description of the New World (1671). Ref: In the late 1630s, Holland attempted to reassert its claim over Brazil by establishing a series of forts along the coastline. One of the best-documented colonies was the expedition led by Prince Maurits of Nassau, who attempted to assemble an intellectual court in the New World. He brought with him a group of highly accomplished artists, mapmakers, and scientists to record the mysteries of Brazil. They included the celebrated painter Frans Post, and the astronomer George Markgraf, who produced the first serious study of the southern sky. Artists and Engravers: Some references mention Bernard Picart as the engraver. We have not been able to verify this. Bernard Picart (1673-1733) was a French painter and engraver. Author: Arnoldus Montanus (c.1625â1683) was a Dutch teacher and author. He published books on theology, history, and geography. Original 1671 engraving. R. Villarreal Collection.
An overhead view of Fortress Sacsayhuaman by E. George Squier.

The Inca fortress of Sacsayhuaman sits on a hill on the northern border of Cusco. The Spanish, in a furious battle over several days, were finally able to overcome General Quizquiz and his warriors and take possession of it. R. Villarreal Collection.
This is the site of the water tower, the Muyumarca, which was located inside the Fortress. Courtesy of Diego Delso.
The serrated northeastern walls of Sacsayhuaman. Courtesy of Diego Delso.
Massive Fortress wall stones. R. Villarreal Collection.
The northern wall of the Citadel. Courtesy of Diego Delso.
Another view of the northeastern walls of the Fortress. R. Villarreal Collection.
View of the walls near the water tower. R. Villarreal Collection.
A look down upon Pisac, with its inca stone ruins on the hillsides. Courtesy of GOPERU.
Another view of Pisac and its ruins. Courtesy of PERUTRAVEL.
More of the Pisac ruins. Courtesy of COMMONSWIKI.
Pisac ruins. Courtesy of Diego Rivas.
More Inca ruins of Pisac. Courtesy of WIKIMED.
Pisac terraces. Courtesy of AUDLEYTRAVEL.
The Quechua Indian market at Chinchero. Courtesy of WIKI.
A Quechua lady selling trinkets at the Chinchero market. Courtesy of MARKLADY TREKKERS.
The Quechua town of Ollantaytambo, the home of the Citadel Ollantaytambo Inca ruins. Courtesy of WIKI.
An Ollantaytambo village street. Courtesy of EDIAS.
A stream flows through Ollantaytambo. Courtesy of WIKICOMMONS.
Ollantaytambo and some of the Citadel ruins. Courtesy of INTREPIDSCOUT.
The Citadel was an imposing collection of forts and storage areas. The steepness of the numerous walls of the several valleys made attacks by the Christians difficult to effect. Courtesy of Wiki.
One of the several forts within the boundaries of the Citadel. R. Villarreal Collection.
A row of stairs within the Citadel. R. Villarreal Collection.
Strange structures on the hill side. Courtesy of TicketMachu.
Terraces viewed from and staircase. R. Villarreal Collection.
Another stairwell. R. Villarreal Collection.
La Paz, with Illimani in the distance (1991).
1931 original photogravure by Atlantis-Verlag of La Paz, with Illimani in the distance. R. Villarreal Collection.

The Tiwanaku (or Tiahuanaco) complex, looking north. Tiahuanaco is a Pre-Colombian archaeological site in western Bolivia. It was the capital of an empire that extended into present-day Peru and Chile, flourishing from AD 300 to AD 1000. The temple complex of Kalasasaya is in the center of the scene. The following pictures show much of the present-day site.
Staircase and entrance door of the Kalasasaya Temple.
Interior walls of the Semi-subterranean Temple with the \"embedded heads\" on its walls.
Another view of the Semi-subterranean Temple courtyard.
The Ponce monolith in the Kalasasaya complex.
The Gateway of the Sun. It stands 10 feet high and 13 feet wide.
A wall decoration of a small god. Courtesy of Viator.
A large courtyard with the Kalasasaya temple behind it. Courtesy of TRAVELPLEASE.
A large bug-eyed stone monolith. Courtesy of LENSTALES.
Another large courtyard with room foundations inside. Courtesy of FREEPIC.
Etching of a ruin in Tiwanaku by E. George Squier.
Etching of Tiwanaku ruin by E. George Squier.
Ruins by E. George Squier.
Etching by E. George Squier.
Our llama arrieros load the animals for the hike into Condoriri and Pequeno Alpamayo.
Earth image of Condoriri, Pequeño Alpamayo, and Huayna Potosi locations.

Condoriri (18,530 feet). Since I was sick the first several days on this expedition, I did not attempt this peak. Two did though and our guide got them to the top of its distinctive summit. Courtesy of Wikipedia.
On the way to Alpamayo.
Pequeno Alpamayo (17,558', 5352 m).
A view to the west.
We inch our way up.
On the top.
On the top with a rope mate.
Cerro Huayna Potosi (19,968', 6086 m).
One rope team nears the summit, out of sight to the right.
We approach a small village on the way to Base Camp. Illimani in distance (21,122', 6438 m).
Above the little village.
Another view.
We near Base Camp.
On the summit.
Our descent down the mountain.

name: A Visit to Machu Picchu

image_matrix.caption: Hiram Bingham discovered and excavated the site of Machu Picchu in 1909 and 1911. His work was presented in National Geographic in three issues, which the author acquired in the 1980's. For his story see, \"Lost City of the Incas.\" Courtesy of BoletoMP.
A look down upon the city with Huyana Picchu behind. Hiram Bingham, April, 1913 National Geographic Magazine.
The lower northern part of the city with much clearing still to be done. Hiram Bingham, April, 1913, National Geographic.
A typical house interior. Hiram Bingham, April, 1913, National Geographic.
The Intihuatana. Hiram Bingham, April, 1913.
A courtyard wall with an entry gate to the right. Hiram Bingham, April, 1913, National Geographic.
Bingham tries to set up his camera stand for some photos. By the way, Kodak supplied all his camera equipment. April, 1913, National Geographic.
The terraces here are still embedded in weeds and vegetation. Hiram Bingham, April, 1913, National Geographic.
Excavating the Chief Temple. Lieutenant Sotomayor, at the right, is in charge. Hiram Bingham, April, 1913, National Geographic.
Notable gables from two important houses in the city. Hiram Bingham, April, 1913, National Geographic.
The interior of these walls are ornamented by a series of symmetrical niches, between each one of which is a projecting stone roughly squared. Hiram Bingham, April, 1913 National Geographic.
The Temple of the Three Windows, called by Bingham the most important in the city. Hiram Bingham, April, 1913 National Geographic.
This is a stylized map of the way to Machu Picchu from Cusco furnished by the Hotel Monasterio.
This train is pulled by a diesel locomotive. When my wife and I first visited Machu Picchu in 1975, PeruRail only had steam engines! Courtesy of PeruRail.

This is an 1839 map of the distribution of plants according to elevation in the Americas. It includes the heights of various mountains around the world and references to both terrestrial and subterranean plants. A beautiful chart drawn and engraved by George Aikman.
The train station in Aguas Calientes 1200 feet below Machu Picchu. Courtesy of G Adventures.
These terraces were for growing fruits and vegetables. Courtesy of FLICKR.
The city with the spiked Huayna Picchu behind. Courtesy of Indian Express.
More structures and terraces. Courtesy of QUASAR.
Buildings with Huayna Picchu behind. Courtesy of CACHI LIFE.
Another part of the city. Courtesy of EARTH TREKKERS.

This is the top of Huayna Picchu. On the Bolivia Expedition, our AAI guides hired a Peruvian guide for Machu Picchu and she led us to the top of Huayna Picchu. One can see the steep terracing where the Indians planted their crops. Amazing! Courtesy of Viator.
Another view of Huayna Picchu. Courtesy of sungatetours.
One can only imagine the intelligence of the Inca engineers! Courtesy of ticketmachu.
It must have been dangerous to tend to the Huayna Picchu terrace crops. Courtesy of goway.
A look down upon Machu Picchu from the summit of Huayna Picchu. Courtesy of littlered.
The summit of Huayna Picchu with Machu Picchu out of sight below. Courtesy of TICKETMP.
More structure foundations. Courtesy of ICUN.
More terraces, these located above the city. Courtesy of PERURAIL.
More terraces and structures. Courtesy of Travel Leisure.
A look down upon Machu Picchu. Courtesy of AGENCIA EFE.
Stairs, terraces, and structure foundations. Courtesy of Britannica.
Strange structures. Courtesy of CLASSADVEN.
Another photo with Huayna Picchu in the distance. Courtesy of CONDE NAST.
More terraces and structures. Courtesy of MACHU TRAVEL.

Sept 11, 2000. A camera crew filming a beer commercial has damaged the most important shrine at the Peruvian Inca citadel of Machu Picchu. A corner of the granite Intihuatana, or \"hitching post of the sun\", was smashed when a camera platform collapsed on top of it. The irregular carved pillar, one of several erected by the Incas at major sites, holds special significance as it was the only Intihuatana not to have been discovered and destroyed by the Spanish conquistadores. The structure is thought to have been an astronomical device, possibly used to predict the solstices of the sun, and is reputed to imbue with energy those who approach it. More than a dozen fragments of rock will be painstakingly reattached, but the changeable and intemperate climate means they could eventually fall off again. \"The damage can probably be repaired but [the Intihuatana] will never be quite the same again,\" said archaeologist Luis Barreda Murillo. Courtesy of MP TRAVEL.
More remnants of this beautiful city. Courtesy of Princess Travel.
It is estimated that 700-800 people occupied Machu Picchu. Courtesy of Pura Adventura. Courtesy of Sacred Sites.
Another display of the intricacies of Machu Picchu. Courtesy of afar media.
A PeruRail train on the return to Cusco. Courtesy of Travel MP.

shortname: The Expedition to Aconcagua in January, 1991.
name: The Expedition to Aconcagua in January, 1991.

ikarus_data.name: The Expedition to Aconcagua in January, 1991.
ikarus_data.shortname: The Expedition to Aconcagua in January, 1991.

image_matrix.caption: Original 1888 wood engraving of Aconcagua, artist unknown. The view is east. Aconcagua was first climbed in 1897 over the western walls by Matthias Zurbriggen, a member of the expedition led by E. A. Fitzgerald. Publisher: Harper & Brothers. R. Villarreal Collection.
An original 1913 half-tone print of Aconcagua. The view is east. Creator: G.P. Putnam's and Sons. R. Villarreal Collection.
At the trailhead of the Rio de las Vacas for the first day of the hike towards the peak.
We cross the de las Vacas later the first day.
A stretch of the de las Vacas on our way to Camp II at Casa de la Piedra.
In the afternoon of the second day, we reach Casa de Piedra for our second camp; Aconcagua is in the distance. The view is west.
Our Camp at Casa de la Piedra. The first view of Aconcagua is from this point.
A climber checks out the stone \"house.\" Courtesy of mza com ar.
Hiking up the Relinchos Valley to Base Camp; Aconcagua on the left, Ameghino on the right.
More of the Relinchos Valley.
The Relinchos stream.
Somewhere in the Relinchos Valley.
Rest stop on the stream.
Approaching Base Camp.
Our Base Camp at 13,000' (4000 m).
An arriero at Base Camp.
Our pack animals.
Above nieves penitentes on the way to Camp I.
A look down the Relinchos River Valley from just below Camp I.
Camp I.
The hike to Camp II at the foot of the Polish Glacier.
Progress towards Camp II.
Getting close.
Camp II - taking a break.
More of Camp II.
The view of Mercedario in the east.
Another vista from Camp II.
And another.
Looking up the impressive Polish Glacier; our route is in the ice and snow to the left.
We left Camp II at 1 AM; here we are at the top of the Glacier looking down its expanse.

We leave our rest stop at the top of the Glacier and strike out for the summit; I'm the one behind the climber immediately in picture. Behind stretches the Relinchos Valley all the way to Casa de Piedra on the de las Vacas. This is one of the most highly sought-after photos of the route pioneered by the Poles in 1934 along their route up the eastern slopes of the great peak. R. Villarreal Collection.
Making steady progress.
One of the team has an upset stomach.
We keep moving higher.
The view to the southwest.

As we approach the summit, a look back down the ridge of our ascent. The rock pinnacles seen in A.26 are just to the left and below the end of the ice ridge. Farther to the left, the Relinchos Valley is in the near distance, with the de las Vacas river in the far distance.
A rest stop near the summit.
Cerro Mercedario (22,047', 6720 m), looking east, from high on Aconcagua.

We're there! I'm on the left.
22,834' (6960 m)
Team photo on the summit.
We descend by way of the Canaleta on the western slopes. A thousand feet lower we traverse around the northern slopes to the eastern side for the return back to Base.
To prevent my frostbitten toes from becoming wet, my friends carry me across the Rio de las Vacas.
Group shot back at Puente del Inca. Though my right toes and fingers were frostbitten, the climb was worth it.
